reviewText: This is a French movie that takes a bit of a different look at the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. A French-Israeli girl asks her soldier brother to throw a message in a bottle into the sea. In it, she asks about the reasons for violence. A group of young men from Gaza find the bottle and one of them decides to answer by e-mail. At first he isn't very friendly, but over time, they develop a more congenial relationship via short e-mail messages. Eventually the boy starts to learn French at a cultural embassy and they begin to converse in French. Over the course of time, both of them run afoul of friends, family or locals who are suspicious. Eventually, war breaks out between Israel and Gaza but neither of them are hurt. The ending is hopeful but not surprising. For those who are interested in a gritty look at the Israeli-Palestinian situation, this movie is really sort of a lightweight version in which the conflict forms a low-key background to a love story. There's really no basis for a relationship between the two characters other than a curiosity about what makes someone from the other side tick and a desire to escape a no-win situation. Many Israeli-Palestinian movies about similar topics are a reflection of the utter hopelessness of the situation. This one, perhaps because it is French, leaves an opening. It doesn't necessarily suggest that there is an end in sight for the conflict, but it does leave a sliver of hope that individuals can rise above the stalemate and establish a basis for trusting relationships. There are certainly movies that do a better job of portraying Middle Eastern conflicts but there are few that do better at showing a relationship that exists between two people separated by uncrossable barriers and with limited opportunities for contact.

reviewText: The two most intractable ethnic/religious conflicts in the world today are the ongoing hostilities between India and Pakistan and that between Israel and the Palestinians in Gaza and the West Bank. This movie is about an online friendship that develops between a young Israeli woman and a young Palestinian man in Gaza.Tal is a 17-year-old girl that has emigrated from France to Jerusalem with her family. Somewhat stunned by the hatred between Israelis and Palestinians, she writes a letter of hope for better things, places it in a bottle and has it thrown into the sea.  The message is received by a young Palestinian called Naim and he replies. This is the beginning of a tender, yet tormented long-distance e-mail relationship between two people that see the hostility and try to do something to reduce it, even though they are overwhelmed by it.Many aspects of the situation between the Palestinians and the Israelis are given in stark detail. The ruthless attitude of Hamas towards any Palestinian that does not strictly follow their designs is demonstrated when Naim is detained and roughly treated. The attitudes of other Palestinians towards Naim when he decides to learn French and applies for a scholarship to go to Paris demonstrate the pressures that can exist when a person tries to break out of the difficulties of living in Gaza.Neither Tal or Naim dare tell people about their communication with a person on the other side and their friendship is strained to the breaking point when the Israeli army attacks Gaza in retaliation for rocket attacks. To me, the most poignant moment of the movie is when Naim leaves Gaza and enters Israel through a security checkpoint on his way to Paris. The decision to have him walk alone through the nearly deserted security building emphasized how isolated a young Palestinian in that situation is and was an act of cinematic genius.If there is ever to be an end to the cycle of despair, destruction and hostility in the Middle East, it will begin with the people on both sides recognizing that those on the other side are people with dreams and aspirations that must be respected if there is to be any form of reconciliation. That is the seed of hope generated in this movie, although it is overwhelmed by all of the hostility.
summary: A tender story of friendship within one of the most intractable conflicts in the world today

reviewText: A Bottle in the Gaza Sea is a love story set against the conflict between Israel and Palestine. This film blew me away.The film opens with a black screen, credit roll, and the sounds of a cafe in the background. The credits finish, the screen stays black, there is the slight sound of an explosion, and then silence. The film gradually opens to reveal somebody lifting a blanket to see daylight. The film is full of the unexpected, there were no dead bodies, no injured, the scene was simply normal life where people were silenced for a few moments during a bomb blast. For both Jerusalem and Gaza, this is an every day event; something they are simply used to. The film then cuts away to an army jeep driving on a beach, a soldier gets out, holding an empty Johnnie Walker Scotch bottle with a note inside. He throws the bottle in the water. The rhythm of the film has been set and it becomes clear there will be two sides to this story.The English translation of the film title put me off. The literal translation from the French is A Bottle in the Sea. In a way, leaving off Gaza would have made this film more approachable for me. Because of the Gaza addition, I expected to be preached to, shouted at, and confused by this film. I am not a student of the Middle Eastern conflict. The news I see and read confuses me. I say that because this film isn't really about that conflict, it is a story about two people from three very different cultures that try to find a common ground and love. The conflict is simply the catalyst that draws these two people together. Watching this film, it is hard not to think of Romeo and Juliette. The thought of that ending was on my mind, especially about the 2/3-point of the film, heightening the tension of the film.The director did an amazing job at showing a beautiful story between two people and at the same time showing how difficult life is on either side. Normal for this country is impossible to understand for anybody not from there. At the end of the film, I felt some small part of the pain.This was a beautifully acted and filmed movie. At an hour and forty minutes it was exactly the right length. Pacing was nearly perfect, the film had a rhythm alternating between the two sides that was a pleasure to watch. Beautiful Agathe Bonitzer, a young French actress with a long filmography, is perfectly cast as Tal. She is defiant, strong, and yet compassionate. Mahmud Shalaby, a handsome young Palestinian actor, is fabulous as Naim. He is the character that changes dramatically in this film, and Shalaby does a great job with that transformation. The supporting cast was so good.The film is presented in French, English, Arabic, and Hebrew (I'm certain I missed a language) with English subtitles. This is no Hollywood film - the language somebody would normally speak, is the language used in the film. The film is not rated, but is probably acceptable for younger viewers. There is no nudity. There is one scene with alcohol. There is very little strong language in the subtitles; a few times the f bomb is there. I imagine this film would be rated PG-13. Parental warning though, in one of the trailers there is frontal female nudity. So oddly, the trailers are R rated.Film Movement got this film absolutely right. There is always a short film on Film Movement DVD's. This time they chose a winner. The short is a twelve minute film about Neve Shalom, a community where Arabs and Jews live together. This is a gorgeous small film that simply says, people are people and when you raise children together, they get along. Children learn not to see the differences but the person. What a perfect message to go along with the feature film.I was provided a copy for review.

reviewText: There are hundreds of films about the Arab/Israeli conflict, but this one definitely rises above the pack. A bottle from a 17 year old Israeli girl is thrown into the Gaza sea.  It is discovered by a 20 year old Palestinian man. The simple note inside the bottle asks the finder to email the girl if the bottle is found. Obviously, the girl wants to communicate to the other side of a war...and to understand someone as a person, not an enemy. (Later she is referred to as "Miss Peace"). In every way, the acting by the two young people feels authentic to me.  The 17 year old girl has a boyfriend, has sex with him, but no real connection.  But through just the internet, and the will of their personalities, the two young people persevere to get to know one another.  Arguably, "Bottle in the Gaza Sea" offers some of the best teenage performance in years.This is not a "coming of age" film. Instead, it is a movie about two open-minded strangers who find a way to relate to each other as friends, despite the fact that so many in their lands prefer to stereotype the "other" just 80 miles away.  The brother of the Israeli girl is quite blunt about the stand he takes....them or us.  However, these two - tentatively - want to discover each other as individuals, not as Israelis or Palestinians, but as ordinary people with hopes and fears and struggles.  In so many ways, the film is universal in scope.  I don't think about it explicitly as an anti war film but rather as a movie to help us understand the humanity of the enemy, if we can escape labeling them.The scene where the male teenager Naim travels from Palestine into Israel, ALONE, through a maze of security checkpoints and procedures, could be considered one of the finest set pieces of world cinema.I also appreciated the fact that neither the Israelis nor the Palestinians are lionized nor demonized.  In fact, their strategy of angry retaliation for violence, then retaliation again, and retaliation again...graphically and brutally illustrates the utter meaningless of that political approach.One caveat, though. The subtitles were very poorly done. I actually had to stand while watching the movie - so as to read everything.  Hope that problem can be corrected in a reissue.  In the 21st century, that oversight is inexcusable.
summary: The Acting by the Two Teenagers is Sensational. - Crossing Lines of Misunderstanding

reviewText: `Une bouteille à la mer' or A Bottle in the Gaza Sea is at once an incredibly tender love story restricted to the Internet and an intensive exploration of both side of the Israeli and Palestinian dilemma that begs for resolution. The story is by Valérie Zenatti and has been adapted for the screen and directed by French writer/director Thierry Binisti.  While the content of the relationship between the main characters is fragile it serves as an exposé of how seemingly impossible life must be living in that small area of the world so vulnerable to repeated hostilities.The film opens sensitively at the beach  - there is a barbed wire barricade separating parts of the beach - and a young man (Eytan Levine - Abraham Belaga) is throwing a whiskey bottle into the ocean. Inside the bottle is a letter from Etyan's sister Tal (Agathe Bonitzer) requesting that whoever finds the bottle to please email her where the bottle was found and who found it. Tal is 17 and has recently moved from France to Jerusalem with her family. She is puzzled by the constant hostilities between the Palestinians in Gaza and the West Bank and the Israelis. When the bottle is discovered it is found by young Naim (Mahmud Shalaby) who at 20 years of age still lives with his mother Intessar (the brilliant actress Hiam Abbass) who works in a hospital (the father is dead) and Naim makes a living delivering Tee Shirts with his cousin whose father makes the Tee Shirts.  There is constant strife in Gaza with the Hamas entering homes and abusing citizens suspected of being traitors and Naim lives in fear after he is interrogated one night.  Naim emails Tal in response to her request for identity of the recipient of her letter and very gradually the two grow to know each other by email. Only 60 miles separate them but many bombings, check-points, sleepless nights and bloodstained days stand between them. Knowing that Tal is French encourages Naim to study French at the French Cultural Institute and his success in earning Tal's language results in his applying for a fellowship to study French in Paris.The Israelis wage war against the Palestinians and Tal's brother Etyan goes to Gaza to fight.  Tal fears for her brother and for Naim. But Naim has found a way out of Gaza by leaving for France - a journey that must begin with crossing through endless barriers to reach Israel to fly to France. Tal and Naim come close to actually meeting at the end of the film but the rest of the story must remain untold for those who have not seen the film.Rarely has a film so judiciously and sensitively show both the Palestinian view as well as the Israeli view in the constant struggle that seems without end.  This film will do more to inform the public about the conflict while sharing one of the most delicate of relationships ever written - the relationship is so very much a mirror of the meanings behind the Israeli Palestinian conflict. It is a rare jewel of a movie. Highly recommended.  Grady Harp, March 13
summary: Borders: 'You think war can be gentle?'

reviewText: The sensitive international drama "A Bottle in the Gaza Sea" reflects on the Israeli and Palestinian conflict in an extremely personal way. It posits that those on both sides hold more common ground than you might imagine. But between history and politics, the bad blood continues into the next generation. With children indoctrinated into preexisting prejudices due to almost constant bloodshed, there seems to be no potential end in sight. What if, however, we could open a dialogue? What if we could see beyond an ideology and see the individuals involved? The confused teen at the heart of Thierry Binisti's heartfelt film is looking for nothing more than understanding. The violence that she witnesses close to home cause her to search for answers, and this quest leads to the unlikely long distance friendship at the heart of the film. In many ways, this is a coming-of-age story told from two unique perspectives. And as both of the story threads play out, the movie expertly contrasts the different worlds as well as showcasing their commonalities.The movie opens with a young soldier throwing a bottle into the Gaza Sea (hey, that would be a great idea for the title). We soon learn that the bottle contains a letter from a young woman in Jerusalem. Tal (Agathe Bonitzer) is a recent transplant from France and is horrified by the violence that she sees on her very street corner. The letter asks for the recipient to email her and describe his/her life to help understand the ongoing conflict. A young Palestinian, Naim (Mahmud Shalaby), is intrigued enough to answer. An initial wariness leads to increasing candor and the two youths find something very special blossoming between them. Each sees a hope in the other to fight for something different, something better. And the movie feels very intimate as the dialogue is exchanged via voice over emails. Ultimately, though, they can't necessarily escape the world into which they were born. But do they have the strength to carve out their own place in it? This relationship is certainly central to "A Bottle in the Gaza Sea," but both Tal and Naim must come to define their own existence."A Bottle in the Gaza Sea" is both melancholy and hopeful in tone and I think that's what makes it well worth a viewing. Both Bonitzer and Shalaby are quite appealing and you'll root for them together and independently. While the movie is filled with great performances (in a myriad of languages), these two keep the focus. And the emotional ending just feels right. The Bonus Short film on the DVD is a really good match to the feature thematically. Called "An Oasis On The Hill," this ten minute documentary feature from France tells the story of an Israeli village where Jews and Arabs have coexisted peaceably for decades. I would love to have seen this extended and expanded upon because it's an incredible topic. Overall, this is a solid movie that helps make international conflict decidedly more intimate. KGHarris, 4/13.
summary: Separated By More Than A Sea: Can You See Past A Lifetime of Hatred And Conflict?

reviewText: I recently saw this movie at the 2013 Jewish and Israeli Film Festival here in Cincinnati. I now notice that this movie is scheduled for a DVD release by Film Movement. I absolutely love the Film Movement library of foreign and indie movies, so this makes complete sense to me."A Bottle in the Gaza Sea" (2011 release from France/Israel; 99 min.) brings the story of the 17 yr. old French-Jewish girl Tal whose family moved from Paris to Jerusalem. Tal is frustrated by the thread of violence from the Gaza Strip and throws a bottle in the sea, hoping someone in Gaza will get it and respond to her invitation to correspond with her via email. A group of young men in Gaza in fact do find the bottle, and 20 yr. old Naim emails her. After initial suspiscion between the two, a fragile friendship develops, and Naim takes up French at the Gaza French Cultural Center, with the hope of eventually getting a scholarship to study in France. Meanwhile Tal's brother Eytan serves in the Israeli Defense Force and is posted at/near the Gaza Strip. Will Eyran come in harm's way? Will Naim get the opportunity to study in France? Will Tal and Naim meet in person? To tell you more would ruin your viewing experience, you'll just have to see for yourself how it all plays out.Several comments: first and foremost, this movie is a prime example showcasing that behind all politics there are people, real human beings with real feelings. While Tal and Naim email back and forth in the beginning, they mistrust each other but eeventually they learn that on the other side there is a real person who probably has little influence over how politics are decided. Second, please note that this movie is NOT a 'romance' movie: Tal and Naim do not 'fall in love' on-line and thankfully we are spared any sentimentailty (as one might have almost certainly gotten in a Hollywood version of this). Third, the movie does an excellent job portraying what families on both sides go through when violence flares up. At a certain point the Palestinians in Gaza and the Israeli military start bombing back and forth, and the expressions of regular families on both sides hiding in basements is the same: pure and utter fear. Last but certainly not least, I found this movie to be a heartfelt cry for mutual respect and understanding, without taking sides as to who is right or who is wrong. Kudos to the organizers of the Jewish and Israeli Film Festival to bring this movie to Cincinnati. Bottom line: "A Bottle in the Gaza Sea" is outstanding and a MUST-SEE for anyone interested in the Israeli-Palestine conflict.
summary: a MUST-SEE for anyone interested in the Israeli-Palestine conflict

reviewText: If you like Israeli movies like I do, I'm sure you will want to see this one.  Although someone might consider the story line "corny," I actually did enjoy the storyline, which goes something like this: a girl who loses a close family member through a terrorist bombing, sends a "message in a bottle" which she drops into the "Gaza Sea" (a possibly fictional sea).  It is, of course, picked up by a gang of Palestinian teenagers, who have been taught to worship the so called martyrs who killed the girl's family member.  The message is essentially a naive "why do people have do such murderous things?"  Eventually the girl makes efforts, and actually does contact one Palestinian boy, and even meets her family.Good by foreign film standards, but only average by American movie standards.
summary: Good, by standards of the foreign film genre
Title: N/A

reviewText: It's 2007. A young Israeli soldier stationed in Gaza drives his jeep to the waterfront and tosses into the sea a bottle. It contains a letter from his 17-year-old sister, Tal, in Jerusalem who hopes it will be found and read and lead to an e-mail friendship across borders.The reply from "Gazaman" is both wary and  smart-alecky. But Tal persists and eventually youth, hope and an unexpected French connection will create a bond and "Gazaman" will reveal himself to be Naim, a  nice guy who's never been out of Gaza and longs to see more of the world. This is the story of how Tal and Naim help each other get their wish. Based on the novel by Valerie Zenati, this is a tale well told, well acted, wrapped in warmth, full of hope and well worth watching, at least once. I've already watched it twice.Also on this disc is a bonus short film, "An Oasis on the Hill," that visits a village where Israelis and Palestinians have lived together peacefully for some 40 years. (And there are some 300 people on the waiting list to get in.)Highly recommended
summary: The story of an Israeli girl who wanted to "friend" a Palestinian and how  that wish came true.
